1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1908

Where did you set up housekeeping?

Where had you been living before that?

For how many people did you prepare meals?

How far was it to your nearest store?

How often could a visit be made to the store?

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it?

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally?

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal?

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

How did you grind it?

Coffee grown.
1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1899

Where did you set up housekeeping? Strickert, Walter Frank

Where had you been living before that? Ridgedale, Sask.

For how many people did you prepare meals? 9-1/2

How far was it to your nearest store? Usually, usually

How often could a visit be made to the store? Usually, usually

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Groceries, Groceries

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it? Usually about 10 lbs. at a time.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 6¢

How much did you use Graham Flour? Usually

Was flour milled locally? Yes

Was flour milled for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? No

Was other grain products did you use? Whole Wheat, Yes

Other? None

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Not often

How did you grind it? By hand with a hand mill

Coffee grown in this area
3. SOURCES AND DIVERSITY

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...100 lb. each month.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Delaware Valley.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...10 oz. Tin.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...By hand.

Name owner, name of farm.

Was the price of buttermilk ...20¢ per quart.

Was the price of cream ...15¢ per quart.

Did you make butter? ...Yes.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early days? ...Meat by kill.

How did you get fresh meat?

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat?

How many meat shops were there?

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood?

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use gas? ...Yes.

Was there a "pork barrel"?

And occasionally a "pork barrel"?

For how long?

What part did this play in the family diet? ...Very seldom.

Was the pork freshly cured or smoked? ...Freshly frozen.

Kind of...
3. SOURCES AND OUTLOOK

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...100 lb. each month.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

First brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Diamond Brand

That date of this corn syrup did you usually buy? ...10/24/37

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...by hand

Was there any creamery near the farm? ...no

What was the price of buttermilk? ...40¢ per lb.

Did you purchase eggs for vitamin? ...yes

Did you raise hens? ...yes

Was kind of cheese? ...not sure

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your next supply in the early years? ...Monthly Home Delivery

How did you get fresh meat? ...not sure

How often did you get fresh meat? ...not sure

How did you preserve meat? ...not sure

How many meat shops were there in your neighborhood? ...not sure

If so what year was it organized? ...not sure

Did you use glass? ...yes

Was meat purchased locally? ...not sure

For how long? ...not sure

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...not sure

Was the fish bought canned or fresh? ...not sure

P.S.

What kind of tea did you buy? At what price?
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Price?
What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store?
If not, where from?
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1909 Carrots 1909 Turnips 1909 Beets 1909 Cabbage 1909 Onions 1909
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?
What weight?
What was the price of prunes?
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?
peas? Yes, beans? Yes, corn? Yes, carrots? Yes, other foods?
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1909
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? No.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? No.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? No.

To what extent?
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, only, seldom, occasionally, frequently, always.
Found to contain a "malt" flavor, and syrup can Jennings were added.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, although dugout). Well - about 30 ft. deep - in summer - ice in winter.

How far was this water from your home? about 150 yds.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

The well was cleaned out once or twice a year. The summer time for the cows was not close enough to keep milk from falling in the well. Many mice came up on the water in the evening pool.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, although dugout). Well - about 30 ft deep - in summer - etc. in winter.

How far was this water from your house? (about 150 yds).

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank).

Recording water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping. Giving dates where possible.

The well was cleaned and overhauled during the summer. The pump was not always easy to keep nice from failing on the well. Many times came up on the latter in the woodland pool.
12. 50429

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes.

If you made your own, did you use soap? No.

What kind of laundry soap did you use?

13. 50429

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood and corn meal.

Where did you get your fuel? Locally from wood - Coal from dealer.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Apples were shipped from Ontario - We used to have them baked at Northern City (name and one other variety, name of which cannot be recalled) each fall.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**April 1st - new baby pork** and eggs - breakfast (coffee) (sandwich)

Potatoes - more pork and eggs; head-potatilla (coffee) (brown)

Pottage, bread, rice or tapioca or soup (tea) (supper)

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1910 - Grandfather, Fred C. Strickert, mother, Ida Strickert, niece - Walter - Frank - William

Also Arnold Entner - bachelor

Also Charles & Ida Entner - Uncle and aunt

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, far with potatoes and vegetables, and poultry and hogs our very near short of food. Wild ducks were plentiful, too.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Apples were shipped from Ontario in barrels - No. 20 and No. 22.

Variety (name of variety) was also used.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - "new belly pork" and eggs - breakfast (coffee) (tea)

Potatoes - "new belly pork" and eggs - breakfast (coffee) (tea)

Potatoes, bread, rice or tapioca or soup (tea) (supper)

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1910 - Grandpa (father), Dad (C. H. Strickert), mother, Nellie

Strickert, none - Walter - Frank - Willie

Also Arnold Butten - bachelor

Also Charles & Ida Butten - Uncle and aunt

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, for with potatoes and vegetables, and poultry and hogs we were never short of food. Wild ducks were plentiful, too.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above—quality, methods of handling, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Potato seed was placed in a flour bin. Then two more bins were started and another row of seed was placed. All done with the old fashioned hoe (wooden handle). In the killing, the plants were used again in seed beds of the new. And in the fall killing, the plants were used and resulted in a heavy crop. Stored in bulk in the dark cellar under the house, the crop of potatoes during early part of each year was directed for them were large amongst the potatoes.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homogrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during phone or days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Potato and was placed in a flour bin. Then two more potatoes were stored and another root of seed was placed. All done with the old fashioned me quartered earthenware bowl.

In the fall, the bowl was used again, on each side of the new. And in the fall before, the bowl was used and resulted in allowing many of the tubers stored in bulk in the dark cellar until the house, the other of harvesting during early part of year, was discarded, for they were large among the potatoes.
OLD ACE.

Can any pleasure in life compare
With a charming drive in the balmy air?
A buggy light with shimmering wheels?
Springs whose resistance you barely feel.
A spirited horse of royal breed
With just a little more style and speed
Than any you meet; and it matters not
If his gait be pace or a swinging trot.
The tassel sways on the graceful whip
You grasp the reins with a lighter grip,
Your horse is off for a splendid dash,
And needs no touch of the urging lash.
You feel the puff of the startled air,
It floats his mane and lifts your hair.
The hoofs mark time in their measured beat,
To the swelling nostrils that scorn defeat.
One glorious day in the balmy Spring King.
John Dore was out with his new horse King.
As he was rich twas his design
To buy a faster horse than mine.
By his side sat the sweetest girl in town
Of handsome features and eyes so brown.
That looking in where the lashes curled
Was like a view of another world.
Where the angels live and the angels sing.
And she was one who had dropped her wins
And had come to earn just to let men see
How sweet the angels in Heaven may be.
I envied the breeze its constant bliss
Or passing her cheek to steal a kiss.
I loved the girl when we both were young.
But getting older, I'd lost my tongue.
I learned in college, Latin and Greek.
But Cupid's language I could not speak,
While Jack was perfect in Cipiti's art.
The only language he knew by heart.
I envied John in his ride
And jogged Old Spot in a leisure way.
That two mile drive to the Shupur Spring
To test the speed of his new horse, King.
John took the lead and it touched his pride
For the fastest horse and the fairest bride
Had been his boast.—"Did I pass him by?"
My heart, I reckon, can answer—why
I'm almost certain I lost that race.
Try lagging behind to look at Grace.
John seemed more proud of his horse that day
Than he did of Grace, which made me say,
"I'll race you back to the town," said I.
"For Grace's glove," but he made reply,
"What use to you is the senseless glove,
From the soft white hand of the girl I love,
Suppose you win," he laughed in my face,
"You get the mitten and I get Grace."
"No Cropper," I said, "I would so prize!"
And caught a look from her soft brown eyes
That drove the rest of it from my head;
I don't remember what I said.
John laughed away until his eyes were wet,
"I increase the wager, I'll take your bet,"
"Why? love," said Grace, "and the hand within
Shall be the prize of the one to win!"
OLD ACE.

Can any pleasure in life compare
With a charming drive in the balmy air?
A buggy light with shimmering wheels feel
Spring's whose resistance you barely feel.
A spirited horse of royal breed
With just a little more style and speed
Than any you meet, and it matters not
If his gait be pace or a swinging trot.
You grasp the reins with a graceful sweep,
Your horse if for a splendid dash,
And needs no touch of the urging last.
You feel the puff of the sturdiest air,
The hoofs mark time in their measured beat,
To the swelling nostrils that seem depart.
One glorious day in the balmy spring King.
John Dore was out with his new horse King.
As he was rich twas his design
To buy a faster horse than mine.
By his side sat the sweetest girl in town
Of handsome features and eyes so brown.
That looking in where the lashes curled
Was like a view of another world,
Where the angels live and the angels sing
And she was one who had dropped her wings
And had come to earth just to let men see
How sweet the angels in Heaven may be.
Or passing her cheek to steal a kiss.
I loved the girl when we both were young.
But getting older I'd lost my tongue.
I learned in college Latin and Greek.
But Cupid's language I could not speak,
While Jack was perfect in Cupid's art.
The only language he knew by heart.
I envied John in his ride that day
And jogged old Spot in a leisure way.
That two mile drive to the sulphur spring.
To test the speed of his new horse, King.
John took the lead and it touched his pride
For the fastest horse and the fairest bride
Had been his boast—Did I pass him by?
My heart, I'm certain I lost that race.
By lagging behind to look at grace.
John seemed more proud of his horse that day
Than he did of Grace, which made me say,
"Be sure & your game before you boast;
Till race you back to the bow," said I.
"For Gracie's love," but he made reply,
"What use to you is the senseless glow,
From the soft white hand of the girl I love,
Suppose you sin," he laughed in my face,
"I'll get Gracie," I said, "I would so prize."
"No trophy," I said, "I would so prize."
And I taught a look from her soft brown eyes
That drove the rest of it from my head.
I don't remember what I said.
John laughed away until his eyes were wet,
"Increase the wager," I'll take your bet,
"My glove," said Grace, "and the hand within
Shall be the prize of the one to win!"
I looked at John but he didn't laugh,
He didn't smile, he didn't chaff,
And also carry said he, "Race you for my bride
Must I," said he, "race you for my bride?"

Her bright eyes flashed her fair cheek glowed,
She took her seat with little ado,
I tucked the rope and my heart in tow,
And rubbed his nose and loosened his neck.

"I said," Old Spot, "as I stroked his neck,
"She's Bob's own Grace if you do your best!"
He pricked his ears if by degrees
Had staked all happiness on his speed.

The time had come when his master's need
Had staked all happiness on his speed.

When all was ready Grace shouted, "Go,"
A word both horses seemed to know,
You heard the hoofs with their measured sway
Pacing along the wreath of silver.

You saw the swell of the panting side,
No word was spoken between two,
The tongue was silent when hope I knew,
A mile a mile and a half we sped.

And still Old Spot was a neck ahead.
I knew Old Spot if he kept that pace
Would win my choice of the human race.

Jack touched his horse with his tasseled whip
Then Grace, pursing her rosy lips
Uttered a sound like a lover's kiss, "Zipp!"

To urge a horse is a capital plan,
And often used to encourage man,
But she never dreamed she had let me in.

To her heart's fond wish that I should win,
The only time in the race she spoke
Was when over-tired Jack's trotter broke.

He's running his horse, and that's not fair!
Then, blushing up to her autumn hair
She grabbed the whip from my willing hand;
A move that John seemed to understand,
For she raised it high as much as to say
Well running's a game that two can play."

So he brought him down to an honest trot,
But couldn't keep up with dear Old Spot
Who forged ahead when he saw that whip.

On, through the village he kept his seed,
For I was too happy to mind the steed.

Nor did he stop when the race was done,
Nor started home with the prize he'd won.

Nor stopped till he reached the farm house gate
Where good old mother was sure to wait.

I know the horse is a trifle old
But you can't buy him with all your gold.

My Grace loves him and hats his neck
And says, "He's the best card in the deck."
And runs his nose till he kisses her face.

She's changed his name to dear Old Ace.
And smiling says, "It's the proper thing."

For it takes the Ace to beat the King."
As she purses her lips for the well-known smack,
I'm glad the queen didn't take the Jack.

Anon.
I looked at John but he didn't laugh,
He didn't smile, he didn't chat.
Must I," said he, "take you for my bride
And also carry the load besides?"

Her bright eyes flashed her fair cheek gloved.
She took the seat with little aid, two necks.
I tucked the rope and my heart is true.
I said, "Old Spot, as I stroked his neck
And rubbed his nose and I loosed his leash.

"He's Bob's own Grace if you do your best!
He pricked his ears when his master's need
Had stoked all happiness on his speed.
When all was ready, Grace shouted, "Go!"
A word both horses heeded to a kno.

Pacing along the great highway.
You heard the swill of the panting side.
You saw the glee in the station beside.
The pink that flows in the sunlight glows.
The card was spoken between them.
Well I educ'd them both.
And still Old Spot was a neck ahead.
I knew Old Spot if he kept that pace
Would win my choice of the human race.

Jack touched his horse with his tasselled whip.
Then Grace, pursing her rosy lips.
Uttered a sound like a lover's kiss "Zipp!"
The world is ruled by a sound like this.
To urge a horse is a capital plan.
And often used to encourage men;
But she never dreamed she had let me in.
To her heart's fond wish that I should win.

The only time in the race she spoke
Was when over tired, Jack's trotter broke.
He's running his horse, and that's not fair!
She grabbed the whip with her willing hand;
For she raised it high, much as to say
"Well running is a game that two can play."
But couldn't keep up with dear Old Spot
Who forged ahead when he saw that whip.
So he brought him down to an honest trot
And passed the village he kept his speed.
On through the village he kept his speed.
Nor I was too happy to mind the street.
Nor did he stop when the race was done.
Nor stood till he reached the farm house gate
Where gold old mother was sure to wait.

I know the horse is a trifling old
But you can't buy him with all your gold.
My Grace loves him and has his neck
And taps his nose till he kisses her face.
She's changed his name to dear Old Ace.
And it takes the Ace to beat the King."
As she purses her lips for the well-known smack,
I'm glad the Queen didn't take the Jack.

Anon.
During July, 1915, father purchased the first tractor and separator in the district; a two cylinder Rumley "Universal" tractor and a 28 inch Amulay separator. Adam Jerry O'Connor, by name, had been recommended as a first class engineer. He arrived from Hamilton, Ont., along with one John Watt, from Almonte, Ont., on a "harvester's excursion." O'Connor was a book-read engineer and failed to do the work expected of him. He advanced the spark so far one of the exhaust valves was burned out as the motor was working against the stroke. Watt was a good worker and he marvelled at the long and large wheat fields. When he returned to his home in Ont. and verified his tales. The brother too, was astonished. One day when the outfit was idle, owing to rain, O'Connor and Watt went for wild ducks, but, in error, they shot all of Mrs. Lee's tame ducks, as they knew no difference.

Re. SOCIAL LIFE.

For social life, we played crokinole for many, many nights. We attended concerts and box socials. At many of the concerts, I rendered many recitations, my preference being the poems, "Old Ace," "1837," "The Women or Humble Head," (a Welsh narrative) and "Let Women Vote." At home, we often had sing-songs of old time songs and ballads. Reading was done considerably by my brothers and parents. Personally, I had stamp-collecting as a hobby.

Re. SIDE WALK WORK.

In June, 1910, father had the contract for sidewalk construction in the town of Strassburg, and we worked for about three weeks. I received $2.50 per hour for ten hours' work and had to pay $25.00 per meal out of my wages. One day a "Land Seeker's" excursion train arrived with many farmers from Iowa. It was sponsored by the William Pearson Land Company. Ted Edwards was the local agent. When the land seekers started from town, the procession of buggies and democrats was almost a mile in length. They went westward to view the land holdings and many sales were made, "on the spot."
During July, 1915, father purchased the first tractor and separator in the district, a two cylinder Rumley, "Universal" tractor and a 28 inch Rumley separator. A man, Jerry O'Connor, by name, had been recommended as a first class engineer. He arrived from Hamilton, Ont., along with one, John Watt, from Almonte, Ont., on a "Harvester's Excursion." O'Connor was a "book-read" engineer and failed to do the work expected of him. He advanced the spark so far one of the exhaust valves was burned out as the motor was working against the stroke. Watt was a good worker and he marvelled at the long and large wheat fields. When he returned to his home in Ont. and reported the length of the fields, he was not believed and in 1916 his brother was sent West with John to verify his tales. The brother, too, was astonished. One day when the outfit was idle, owing to rain, O'Connor and Watt went for wild ducks, but, in error, they shot all of Mrs. Lee's tame ducks, as they knew no difference.

For social life, we played crokinole for many, many nights. We attended concerts and box socials. At many of the concerts, I rendered many recitations, my preference being the poems, "Old Ace," "1857," "The Women of Mumbles Head," (a Welsh narrative) and more, with my favorite encore being, "Let Women Vote." At home, we often had "sing-songs" of old time songs and ballads. Reading was done considerably by my brothers and parents. Personally, I had stamp-collecting as a hobby.

In June, 1910, father had the contract for sidewalk construction in the town of Strassburg, and we worked for about three weeks. I received 20¢ per hour for ten hours' work and had to pay 25¢ per meal out of my wages. One day a "Land-Seeker's" excursion train arrived with many farmers from Iowa. It was sponsored by the William Pearson Land Company. Mr. Ted Edwards was the local agent. When the land seekers started from town, the procession of buggies and democrats was almost a mile in length. They went Westward to view the land holdings and many sales were made, "on the spot."
Re. STORM. On June 30th, 1912, my two brothers and I were visiting at the J.C. Pelle home, 2½ miles North and ½ mile West. About 4:30 p.m., a heavy, rolling cloud was seen in the far South-west. About 5 o'clock, we decided to start for home, possibly near or around 5 o'clock.

We hitched out driving team to the two seated democrat and started for home. We drove the half mile East and when we turned to go South, the storm broke and rain piled down in very heavy sheets or torrents. So much so, that the water ran on our way. We stopped at the William Snow farm until the rain stopped. This was the storm that caused the Regina cyclone.

Re. STONES. When the homestead was being "broken up", or the virgin sod turned over, there were many stones to be dug and hauled away. The usual day's haul was ten wagon loads. Many small piles - perhaps 60 to 80 small stones were often found in one heap.

Reported to us by other settlers as being Indian grave markers. In our haste to clear the area, no effort was ever made to ascertain if this report was truth or fancy. When loading the wagon, large stones too heavy to lift were rolled up on a plank. Very large stones were rolled out of the ground by the use of a logging chain and horse power. When the land was being plowed the first time (breaking) a man would follow the plow to dig out the stones that the plow had struck. The task of stone hauling was very heavy and very tiring.

Re. FAIRS. The Strassburg Agricultural Fair was an eagerly anticipated annual event, when nearly everyone in the district would go as to a celebration. It was another holiday of the midsummer. The Fair Grounds would be decorated for the occasion and the admission charges assisted the Society to meet the financial needs.

Re. RINK. An early Strassburg store-owner was Mr. Ed. Morton, who was also on the committee formed in town to have a Curling and Skating rink erected. Rather draw a rough sketch of a truss form of rink rather to span the 50 feet of the skating area, to be free of any post support. Construction began during November and was completed on December 31st, 1909. We had gone to town that day to get father and his other helpers on the rink. The morning was very mild and around 3 p.m. it started to cloud over. Never having experienced a blizzard, we started for home, wax as there was a blizzard starting. After supper in town, we started for home with the storm breaking. The horses kept the trail for about 2 miles until we got to the hills where there was more bush shelter. The storm increased steadily. When we were about 7 miles from home, one of our horses slipped on ice, and with a bad leg condition, was unable to get up without help. The men helped to get her up and we eventually got home. The storm lasted for two or three days, and caused a lot of suffering.
Re. STORM. On June 30th, 1912, my two brothers and I were visiting at the J.C. Pelle home, 2½ miles north and ¼ mile west. About 4:30 p.m., a heavy, rolling cloud was seen in the far southwest. We decided to start for home, possibly near or around 5 o'clock.

We hitched out driving team to two seated democrats and started for home. We drove the half mile east and when we turned to go south, the storm broke and rain pelted down in very heavy sheets or torrents. So much so, that the water ran to the front of the democrat when we were going down hill on our way. We stopped at the William Snow farm until the rain stopped. This was the storm that caused the Regina cyclone.

Re. STONE HAULING. When the homestead was being "broken up", or the virgin sod turned over, there were many stones to be dug and hauled away. The usual day's haul was ten wagon loads. Many small piles—perhaps 60 to 80 small stones were often found in one heap.

In our haste to clear the area, no effort was ever made to ascertain if this report was truth or fancy. When leading the wagon, large stones too heavy to lift were rolled on a plank. Very large stones were rolled out of the ground by the use of a logging chain and horse power. When the land was being plowed the first time (breaking), a man would follow the plow to dig out the stones that the plow had struck. The task of stone hauling was very heavy and very tiring.

Re. FAIRS. The Strassburg Agricultural Fair was an eagerly anticipated annual event, when nearly everyone in the district would go as a celebration. It was another holiday of the midsummer. The Fair Grounds would be decorated for the occasion and the admission charges assisted the Society to meet the financial needs.

Re. RINK. An early Strassburg store-owner was Mr. Ed. Morton, who was also on the committee formed in town to have a curling and skating rink erected. Father drew a rough sketch of a truss form of rafters to span the 50 feet of the skating area, to be free of any post support. Construction began during November and was completed on December 31st, 1909. We had gone to town that day to get father and his other helpers on the rink. The morning was very mild and around 3 p.m. it started to cloud over. Never having experienced a blizzard, we started for home 9½ miles away. Some folks advised us not to leave, we started for home with the storm breaking. After supper in town, we started for home with the horses kept where there were more about 2 miles until we got to the hills where there was a bush shelter. The storm increased steadily. When we were about 7 miles from home, one of our horses slipped on ice, and with a bad leg condition, was unable to get up without help. The storm helped to get her up and we eventually got home. The storm lasted for two or three days, and caused a lot of suffering.
Re. DOG.

An uncle of mine, Louis Strickert of Sebringville, Ontario, (near Mitchell and Stratford, Ont.) arrived at our home after a rail trip in charge of the Clydesdale stallion, "Kinniard Chief," and he brought a two year old Scotch collie dog, called "Fred" by name. The morning after his arrival, I walked to the nearby pasture and milked two cows. I then opened the pasture gate and allowed the herd of about fifteen cattle to go out to better grass. All of this action could be seen from the farm dwelling. The dog had been with me all the time. I walked back to the house with the milk. Uncle Louis told us the dog could be told to go back and put all the cattle in the pasture again. This, none of us would believe, but as Uncle insisted on doing so, father consented at last. The dog was told to, "Put those cattle back in the pasture!" Away went the dog and gently nosed the cattle back and then came to the house. Watching this performance, father bought the dog that morning for $50.00, and he was a good, faithful dog for many years until his death about the age of fourteen or fifteen years.

Re. WAR.

In the early days of road construction, horses were used with "slushers", or "fresnoes," with the operator walking behind. Certain road construction was being done near the corner of Sec. 36-24-21 W2nd, when one of the workmen got a newspaper in the mail delivered by a neighbour, telling of the outbreak of World War I. This was hard to believe but it was a true fact. There was no telephone system in the district at such time. During the following days of War, the weekly papers carried long lists of casualties, those killed in Action and Wounded. Full pages of names were common and it was the practice to closely scan through the lists for the names of district volunteers who had gone Overseas.

Re. HUNTING.

Hunting in the early years was a help in the food supply. Our hunting as principally for wild ducks, partridges, Prairie chicken and rabbits (both cottontail and jack), all used for food. There were many ducks on the sloughs of the Last Mountain hills, around here. Some people were able to obtain venison, but all we ever had were gifts from neighbours. Coyote hunting was more as a protection of the poultry than for sport. However, with coyote pelts being worth $8.00 each, whenever a horse or a head of cattle died, either naturally or by accident, the carcass was placed in a spot screened from sight by the coyote eating on it. We had a .32 calibre Winchester rifle and a .25-.20 Savage carbine, also an old Swiss army rifle which was very heavy and unreliable for discharge. Ammunition was very cheap and much was used for target practice. One of the really active hunters of the district was one, Charlie Lee, who did his hunting on horseback and who was a very good shot with a rifle.
Re: DOG.

An uncle of mine, Louis Strickert of Beringville, Ontario, (near Mitchell and Stratford, Ont.) arrived at our home after a rail trip in charge of the Clydsdale stallion, "Ramford Cigar" and he brought a two year old Scotch collie dog called Weazelboy by name. The morning after his arrival I walked to the nearby pasture and killed two cows. I then opened the pasture gate and allowed the herd of about fifteen cattle to go out to better grass. All of this action could be seen from the farm dwelling. The dog had been with me all the time. I walked back to the house with the milk. Uncle Louis told us the dog could be told to go back and put all the cattle in the pasture again. This none of us would believe, but as Uncle Irving insisted, on doing so, father consented at last. The dog was told to, put those cattle back in the pasture! Away went the dog and gently nosed the cattle back into the pasture. My father bought the dog that morning for $50.00 and he was a good fatherly dog for many years until his death about the age of fifteen or fifteen years.

Re: WAR.

In the early days of road construction, horses were used with messengers, or messengers with the operator walking behind. Certain road construction work done near the corner of Sec. 36-24-21 W2nd, when one of the workmen got a newspaper in the mail delivered by a neighbour twirling it up in his feet. This was hard to believe but it was true enough.

There was no telephone system in the district at such time. There was no wireless during the following days of WWI. The weekly papers carried long lists of casualties, those killed in action and wounded. Full pages of names were common and it was the practice to closely scan through the list for the names of district volunteers who had gone overseas.

Re: HUNTING.

Hunting in the early days was quite extensive for wild ducks, pheasants (both cottontail and jock), all used for meat, and rabbits (both cottontail and jack). There were many ducks on the sloughs or the East Mountain, thin hills around home. Some people were able to obtain venison, but we all was here used for the people's影视. Coyote hunting was more for protection of the poultry than for sport. However, width coyote pelts being worth $8.00 each, whenever a horse or a head of cattle died, either naturally or by accident, there was a hinges on it. We had a No. 252 carbine, also an old Swiss army which was very heavy and unreliable for discharge. Ammunition was very cheap and much was used for target practice. One of the men active hunters on horseback and who was a very good shot with a rifle.
Re. FIRE.

On April 5th, 1910 there was a heavy growth of "prairie-wool" covering the land on the Last Mountain Hills. On this date a big fire was burning North of Strassburg, fanned by a South wind. It burned on towards the town of Drayton. On April 6th, the wind shifted and came from the West, driving the fire to the Last Mountain hills. We had been hauling stones in the forenoon. About 4 p.m., an arm of the fire passed to the South of our homestead, but the main fire was still to the West. About 5 p.m., if was coming and we tried to back-fire to check it by firing along the plowed fire-guard, but our effort was too late for the fire jumped the 24 furrow guard and passed on out barnyard. The hay stack was soon afire, and our sheep and horses and a cow but lost a calf in the ensuing fire. The new farm dwelling was endangered but the piles of cellar clay did help to protect it. The fire did reach one part of the house but a few shovelfuls of clay extinguished it. The horses and the cow were held on the field of breaking South of the house. The fire raced Eastward but left a large area of prairie wool along the East side of our homestead. At near 10 p.m. the fire was backing up against the still high wind and we plowed a furrow to check the back-fire. This was the only area of native grass left for many miles around, and it was needed for stock feed. A hand scythe was used by us the first few days after the fire to give to each horse and to the cow, a bag full of hay. We lost a pile of oats, covered by a tent, some harness and parts; the poultry house and the stable. Around 10 p.m., the fire was burning towards the Touchwood Hills and the flickering lights were like a distant city. The fire was reported to have started at Mr. Christoff's farm and it caused many farmers to have a heavy loss. Mr. William Snow lost all his buildings except his dwelling. Others lost buildings and feed. Animal feed was at a premium and was hard to acquire, and much driving to get it.
Re. FIRE.

On April 5th, 1910, there was a heavy growth of "prairie-wool" covering the land near the Last Mountain Hills. On this date, a big fire was burning North of Strassburg, fanned by a South wind. It burned on towards the town of Duval. On April 6th, the wind shifted and came from the West, driving the fire to the Last Mountain hills. We had been hauling stones in the forenoon. About 4 p.m., an arm of the fire passed to the South of our homestead, but the main fire was still to the West. About 5 p.m. it was coming and we tried to back-fire to check it by back-firing along the plowed fire-guard, but our effort was too late for the fire jumped the 24 furrow guard and passed on to our barnyard. The hay stack was soon afire, and our straw and manure packed stable too. We rushed in and save the three horses and a cow, but lost a calf in the ensuing fire. The new farm dwelling was endangered but the piles of cellar clay did help to protect it. The fire did reach one part of the house but a few shovelful's of clay extinguished it. The horses and the cow were held on the field of breaking South of the house. The fire raced Eastward but left a large area of prairie wool along the East side of our homestead. At near 10 p.m. the fire was backing up against the still high wind and we plowed a furrow to check the back-fire. This was the only area of native grass left for many miles around, and it was needed for stock feed. A hand scythe was used by us the first few days after the fire, to give to each horse and to the cow, a bag full of hay. We lost a pile of oats, covered by a tent, some harness and parts; the poultry house and the stable. Around 10 p.m., the fire was burning towards the Touchwood Hills and the flickering lights were like a distant city. The fire was reported to have started at a Mr. Christoff's farm and it caused many farmer to have a heavy loss. Mr. William Snow lost all his buildings except his dwelling. Others lost buildings and feed. Animal feed was at a premium and was hard to acquire, and much driving to get it.
Oxford
